1815-1834 The Records of the American Society for Educating Pious Youth for Gospel Ministry is a collection of annual reports of the society from 1815-1834.

The original order of the collection was retained, and this collection is arranged chronologically.

Historical Note
The American Society for Educating Pious Youth for the Gospel Ministry was founded in 1815, with the intention of increasing the numbers of ministers within the United States. The organizers felt that there were not enough men being educated as ministers, and that a vast percentage of the population were without religious guidance and instruction. Therefore, the mission of the society was to provide financially for young men who wished to join the ministry, but could not afford such an education. The society changed its name to the American Education Society in 1820, and continued to function as a scholarship organization that provided financial support for students in theology programs.
The Rev. Dr. Woods, Rev. Joshua Bates and Mr. John Adams are listed in the first journal as the first leaders of the organizations. A few notable figures from NYU and American history include; Gardiner Spring; James M. Matthews, the 1st chancellor of NYU; William Patton; James Milnor; Frances Scott Key; and Hon. Theodore Frelinguysen, the 2nd Chancellor of NYU, and later President of Rutgers University.
Scope and Content Note
This collection is made up of annual reports from the American Society for Educating Pious Youth for Gospel Ministry. The first document in this collection is dated 1815, the year of the first annual meeting of directors. The journals on file document meetings up to 1834, although the society continued to function under various names well into the 20th century.
A constitution was adopted on August 29th, 1815, outlining the terms of admission and subsistence within the organization, and the constitution was printed in every subsequent report. Each of the reports also contain a yearly summary of the activities of the organization, lists of beneficiaries, donors, lifetime members (people who gave a sum of $100 at any given time were considered automatic lifetime members); and annual subscribers.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
The collection was transferred from NYU's Washington Square Library to the University Archives sometime prior to August 1990.
